title: 113_hr4171
content: The "Labor Statistics Improvement Act" establishes the Commission to Improve Labor Statistics with the duty of enhancing labor statistics. The Commission established by the "Labor Statistics Improvement Act" is tasked with examining the Bureau of Labor Statistics' process for collecting and reporting unemployment data, including methods for determining who is actively looking for work. Recommendations for improvements and alternative measures of labor force participation are to be formulated. The Commission established by the "Labor Statistics Improvement Act" is examining the accuracy of the official unemployment rate and how it reflects labor market strength. They are also looking into how unemployment rates may vary over a business cycle due to changes in labor force participation. Additionally, they aim to develop new methods for determining underemployment by considering workers not in jobs that match their skill set or education and those earning less than others in similar occupations. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP OF COMMISSION. The Commission, established by the "Labor Statistics Improvement Act," consists of four members appointed from the private sector, academia, or Federal civil service, with expertise in economic analysis, labor markets, or statistical analysis. Members are appointed by the President, President pro tempore of the Senate, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without basic pay and receive travel expenses. The Commission consists of four members appointed from various sectors with expertise in economic analysis, labor markets, or statistical analysis. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. Three members constitute a quorum, with the Chairperson elected by the members and meetings held at their call. The Chairperson appoints Commission staff, who are subject to certain civil service laws. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission is required to submit a report. The Commission must submit a detailed report to the President and Congress within 180 days of all original members being appointed. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the report, during which it can conclude its activities and provide testimony to Congress.
